title: Message to Millennials: Stop Buying French Castles
text:
This column is part of the Journal’s “The New Rules of Money” package about the financial challenges facing young adults.

The Journal biz editors asked me to address today’s young people on financial planning matters, which is a horrid idea, as I recently turned 500 years old, and I just spent the last two dollars I possess for an ice cream sandwich, which, to be truthful, wasn’t my first of the day.

My bosses also made a big stink about telling me to not write anything condescending in this piece. Apparently, young people today are routinely talked down to by financial advisers, who rudely assume anyone under 40 is a debt-soaked avocado-toast-hoarding Instagram junkie who will never buy a home or a car.

Fine, OK. But I’m also an unrepentant truth teller, and I need to give today’s young people honest advice about their finances:

Stop Buying French Castles, Dammit!If I run into one more 20-something in the Journal offices who wants to regale me with their recent purchase of a château in Provence, I am going to scream. Kids today need to stop buying these things. I don’t know why young people are obsessed with buying 16th-century Gallic castles, I don’t know if the banks are getting goofy with loans, but you have to stop. Buy too many castles, and you’re never going to be able to afford one of those starter New York City apartments, with a toilet in the kitchen.

Private Jet Travel Only for Flights Over Eight Hours. Self explanatory. If you’re under 30 and you’re spending more than $14 million a year on air travel, that is going to start adding up fast.

Generation Z is the stuffed-animal generation. Photo: Getty Images/iStockphoto

Enough with the Stuffed Animals Maybe you didn’t know this, but members of Generation Z are still crazy about their stuffed animals. Many of them traipse through the workplace with a large mesh satchel of “stuffies” (bunnies, kitties, dragons, unicorns) they have owned since childhood, and they keep adding to their collections. It’s not unusual to meet a young person who owns more than $1.2 million in stuffies. Enough! Part of being a mature adult is wasting money on important things, like Springsteen tickets, and vacations in Tulum.

College. For some reason, young people still insist on going to college, when there is nothing you can learn at Harvard or Stanford that you can’t learn on YouTube in six minutes. It feels like a giant waste of money and time, and, thanks to the FBI, you can’t even get to college by pretending you’re a varsity rower anymore. Lame.

Now is the time to stockpile Juul. Photo: Bloomberg

Stockpile Juul. Everyone under 50 vapes, it’s just a fact. But the health science is worrisome, and the government is cracking down. That doesn’t mean it can’t be a prime investment opportunity. Rent a storage space, and begin stockpiling flavors, especially mango. When Vape Prohibition comes around, you’ll be the Juul Al Capone, and then you can buy whatever castle you want.

When did hard seltzer become this silly craze? Photo: Richard B. Levine/Zuma Press

Take It Easy on the Flavored Seltzer. This one is actually true. I don’t know when fancy seltzer became such a craze, but it’s silly. Your grammy used to get seltzer delivered once a week, by a horse, and it cost 50 cents a week. She didn’t need “hard seltzer” or White Claw or any of that nonsense. That is what gin is for, kids.

There you go. Those are my financial tips for young people. My editors also wanted me to offer advice about things like splitting the check when you go out to dinner. Do I really need to explain this? Just take the check, and divide it by however many people are out at dinner, minus yourself. Collect all the money, and hop into a cab before anyone figures out what you did.

But please: don’t buy a stuffed animal with it.

Write to Jason Gay at Jason.Gay@wsj.com
description: Some other financial advice from a 500-year-old columnist: Go easy on the stuffed animals and the fancy seltzer.
